https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The study of the chemical composition of materials and components making up the surficial, weathered, and usually unconsolidated layer that nearly everywhere forms the surface of the land and overlies or covers the bedrock. Regolith includes rock debris of all kinds, volcanic ash, glacial drift, alluvium, loess and eolian deposits, vegetal accumulations, and soil.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia. Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011).

https://prez.dev/description.@value: The study of the chemical composition of materials and components making up the surficial, weathered, and usually unconsolidated layer that nearly everywhere forms the surface of the land and overlies or covers the bedrock. Regolith includes rock debris of all kinds, volcanic ash, glacial drift, alluvium, loess and eolian deposits, vegetal accumulations, and soil.

The study of the chemical composition of the unconsolidated mineral or organic material on the surface of the earth that serves as a natural medium for the growth of land plants, and whose formation is conditioned by relief and controlled by genetic and environmental factors such as climate (including water and temperature effects) and biological activity (macro- and micro-organisms) acting on parent material over a period of time.
